questionList.questionText: A 3-year-old African American boy is brought to the emergency department for fever.  Since returning from a family trip to Nigeria last week, he has been lethargic with constant nausea and headache.  He has had several episodes of vomiting and watery diarrhea each day and high spiking fevers, chills, and drenching sweats every other day.  The boy carries the sickle cell trait and has no other medical problems.  He takes no medications and his vaccinations are up to date.  His temperature is 40 C (104 F), blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, pulse is 132/min, and respirations are 24/min.  Examination shows a tired-appearing boy with jaundice.  Lungs are clear to auscultation.  The abdomen is soft and nontender.  Hepatosplenomegaly is present.  Range of motion in his neck and extremities is normal.  Laboratory studies show mild anemia and thrombocytopenia.  Which of the following factors is associated with decreased morbidity from this illness?
questionList.explanationText:
This child's clinical presentation is concerning for malaria, a dangerous parasitic infection transmitted by mosquitos in tropical regions worldwide.  Almost 2000 people die from malaria every day.  Plasmodium falciparum is the primary cause of morbidity and mortality in sub-Saharan Africa.  Cyclic fevers (eg, every 2 or 3 days) with other nonspecific systemic symptoms are the key features of malarial illness (Table).  The febrile paroxysms parallel the waves of red blood cell invasion when parasites are released from the liver into the bloodstream.  Diagnosis is confirmed by microscopic visualization of Giemsa-stained parasites on thick and thin blood smears.

Carriers of the sickle cell trait are inherently protected from severe disease, as the misshapen red blood cells create a suboptimal environment for parasitic proliferation.  Patients with a past history of malarial infection are also at relatively low risk for severe disease on reinfection due to partial immunity.

(Choice A)  Acute hepatitis A infection can cause fever, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, hepatomegaly, and jaundice.  However, this patient's cyclic fevers are suggestive of malaria rather than hepatitis.

(Choice B)  Neisseria meningitides vaccination can prevent infection from serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135.  Meningitis causes fever and severe headaches, but patients usually have neck stiffness and photophobia as well.  In addition, bacterial meningitis causes precipitous neurologic decline within hours of onset.

(Choices C and F)  Both sexes are equally susceptible to malaria.  However, infants and young children are at increased risk for life-threatening complications, such as cerebral malaria (eg, seizures, delirium, coma).

(Choice D)  Ciprofloxacin is not recommended for malaria prophylaxis.  It can treat traveler's diarrhea caused by Escherichia coli, Campylobacter jejuni, Shigella, and Salmonella.  However, bacterial enteritis typically resolves within 5 days and would not cause periodic fevers.

Educational objective:
Malaria should be suspected in any ill patients, especially those with a history of febrile paroxysms, who have traveled to an endemic-tropical region.  Thick and thin blood smears should be ordered for parasite detection and quantification.  Nonimmune children are at highest risk of death, but the sickle cell trait confers some protection from severe complications.

questionList.questionText:
A 32-year-old man comes to the physician with a 2-day history of fever, headache, malaise, and myalgias.  Family members say that he seems slightly confused.  He recalls getting a tick bite 2 weeks ago while walking through the woods in Arkansas.  His temperature is 39 C (102 F), blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 100/min.  His neck is supple and there is no lymphadenopathy.  The oropharynx is clear.  Cardiovascular examination is unremarkable.  The abdomen is soft and nontender.  There is no rash.  There are no focal neurologic deficits.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
    Hemoglobin14.0 g/dL
    Platelets78,000/µL
    Leukocytes2,500/µL
        Neutrophils56%
        Eosinophils1%
        Lymphocytes33%
        Monocytes10%
Liver function studies
    Total protein6.5 g/dL
    Total bilirubin1.0 mg/dL
    Alkaline phosphatase110 U/L
    Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT)98 U/L
    Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT)105 U/L

What is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Human monocytic ehrlichiosis

Epidemiology

  • Transmitted by tick vector (Lone Star tick)
  • Seen in southeastern & south central United States

Clinical manifestations

  • Flu-like illness (high fever, headache, myalgias, chills)
  • Neurologic symptoms (confusion)
  • Rash (<30% in adults) is uncommon ("Rocky Mountain spotted fever without the spots")

Laboratory findings

  • Leukopenia & thrombocytopenia
  • Elevated liver enzymes & lactate dehydrogenase

Diagnosis

  • Intracytoplasmic morulae in monocytes
  • PCR testing for Ehrlichia chaffeensis/E ewingii

Treatment

  • Empiric doxycycline while awaiting confirmatory testing

This vignette depicts a patient with a typical case of ehrlichiosis.  Ehrlichiosis is a tick-borne infection caused by Ehrlichia chaffeensis and E ewingii.  These bacteria are carried by ticks, including the lone star tick (Amblyomma americanum), found in the southeastern and south central United States.  The principal reservoir is the white tail deer.

Ehrlichiosis is characterized by an acute febrile illness with malaise and altered mental status.  Ehrlichiosis is not often associated with a rash (<30% in adults) and is described as "Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF) without the spots."  Neurologic symptoms may include confusion, mental status changes, clonus, and neck stiffness.  Laboratory studies often show leukopenia and/or thrombocytopenia, along with elevated aminotransferases and lactate dehydrogenase.

The diagnosis is often clinical, although definitive diagnosis can be made through visualization of intracytoplasmic morulae in white blood cells or through polymerase chain reaction testing.  Doxycycline is the appropriate treatment and is often initiated empirically when the diagnosis is suspected while confirmatory testing is pending.

(Choices A and F)  Elevated liver enzymes and hematologic abnormalities, including leukopenia and thrombocytopenia, can be attributed to ehrlichiosis.  As a result, hepatitis serologies and bone marrow biopsy would not be warranted.

(Choices B and G)  Ceftriaxone is used for the treatment of neurologic and cardiac manifestations of Lyme disease.  Several factors make Lyme disease less likely in this patient.  Ixodes scapularis, the tick that carries Borrelia burgdorferi, is not commonly found in the southern United States.  The majority (80%) of patients with early localized (primary) Lyme disease (within days of the tick bite) have the classic erythema migrans rash with or without constitutional symptoms.  The absence of a rash and the presence of a high fever and hematologic and liver enzyme abnormalities make Lyme disease less likely.  Finally, this patient does not exhibit any prominent neurologic (eg, encephalitis, cranial nerve palsy, radiculopathy) or cardiac (eg, heart block, pericarditis) manifestations of early disseminated (secondary) Lyme disease.  These would more commonly occur several weeks to months after the initial tick bite.  Given the low suspicion for the disease, Lyme serologies would not be indicated.  Even if this patient has Lyme disease, doxycycline would be sufficient to treat it.

(Choice C)  Chloramphenicol is a second-line treatment option for ehrlichiosis and RMSF.  It is associated with blood dyscrasias and is not commonly used.  In 90% of RMSF patients, a maculopapular rash (involving the soles and palms) occurs a few days after the onset of fever.  The presence of leukopenia and absence of rash in this patient are more suggestive of ehrlichiosis than RMSF.  Doxycycline is the first-line treatment.

(Choice E)  Erythromycin is not an effective treatment for ehrlichiosis.  It has activity against Legionella and Mycoplasma.

Educational objective:
Ehrlichiosis should be suspected in a patient from an endemic region with a history of tick bite, febrile illness with systemic symptoms, leukopenia and/or thrombocytopenia, and elevated aminotransferases.  Rash is uncommon, and the drug of choice is doxycycline.

questionList.questionText: A 37-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to 5 days of fever, chills, malaise, headache, and fatigue.  The patient's temperature has fluctuated between 37 C (98.6 F) and 41 C (105.8 F).  She has been taking ibuprofen, which improves the fever.  The patient took a 7-day vacation to Southeast Asia a month ago.  Temperature is 39.9 C (103.8 F), blood pressure is 110/66 mm Hg, pulse is 112/min, and respirations are 20/min.  On physical examination, the patient appears tired and has mild scleral icterus.  There are no oropharyngeal lesions, lymphadenopathy, or rash.  The lungs are clear on auscultation and no cardiac murmurs are present.  The liver is slightly tender to palpation, and the spleen tip is palpable below the left costal margin.  Neurologic examination shows no signs of meningeal irritation.  Which of the following is the best next step in diagnosis of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Malaria

Epidemiology

  • Vector: female Anopheles mosquito
  • 4 major species of Plasmodium: P falciparum, P vivax, P ovale, P malariae
  • Highest burden of disease is in Africa but is found in most tropical/subtropical areas worldwide

Manifestations

  • Periodic febrile paroxysms
  • Nonspecific malaise, headache, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, myalgia

Complications

  • Cerebral (eg, delirium, seizure), hypoglycemia, ARDS, acidosis, renal/hepatic failure, coagulopathy

Diagnosis

  • Thin & thick peripheral blood smears
  • Rapid testing

ARDS = acute respiratory distress syndrome.

Malaria should be suspected in any traveler who returns from an endemic region and develops febrile illness.  Although initial symptoms (eg, malaise, myalgia, arthralgia, headache, vomiting, diaphoresis, cough, abdominal tenderness) are often nonspecific, the following manifestations increase the pretest probability of infection:

  • Fever paroxysms:  Initially, patients develop high fevers (often >40 C [104 F]) at irregular periods.  After several days, fevers tend to occur at regular intervals every 24-48 hours due to synchronized rupture of erythrocytes by merozoites.

  • Mild splenomegaly:  Lysed erythrocyte fragments and infected erythrocytes are culled from the bloodstream by macrophages in the spleen, which can cause mild splenomegaly.

  • Jaundice:  Erythrocyte rupture releases heme into the bloodstream, which can cause hyperbilirubinemia with scleral icterus/jaundice.

  • Anemia and mild thrombocytopenia:  Anemia occurs due to intravascular hemolysis; thrombocytopenia may occur due to consumption of platelets in the microvasculature in response to increased adhesion molecules on infected erythrocytes.

The diagnosis is confirmed by identifying the parasite on Giemsa-stained peripheral blood smear, which quantifies the degree of parasitemia and identifies the infecting species (each appears different under microscopy).  Rapid diagnostic tests are widely available in resource-limited countries; although these can be used where there is no electricity or advanced laboratory equipment, they provide only qualitative results.  Therefore, blood smear is generally preferred for diagnosis when available.

(Choice A)  Standard blood cultures cannot diagnose malaria but can diagnose typhoid fever, which is common in travelers and frequently causes waxing-and-waning temperature elevations.  However, patients classically have relative bradycardia, rose spots, and, eventually, severe intraabdominal complications (eg, bowel perforation).

(Choice C)  Acute HIV infection frequently causes a febrile syndrome with nonspecific symptoms a few weeks after transmission.  However, patients often have lymphadenopathy, rash, and oropharyngeal ulcers.  In addition, acute HIV rarely causes icterus.

(Choice D)  Entamoeba histolytica is a common cause of colitis in travelers to endemic regions.  Although it can also rarely (<1%) cause amoebic liver abscess, E histolytica infection is not usually associated with splenomegaly or jaundice.

(Choice E)  Hepatitis A infection is typically marked by nonspecific symptoms followed by jaundice, light-colored stools, and dark urine.  Although patients often have hepatomegaly, splenomegaly is relatively uncommon.  In addition, wide swings in fever raise suspicion for an alternate diagnosis.

Educational objective:
Malaria should be suspected in any traveler who returns from an endemic region and develops febrile illness.  Patients often have periods of fever >40 C (104 F), mild splenomegaly, jaundice, anemia, and thrombocytopenia.  Most cases are diagnosed using thin and thick blood smear with Giemsa stain, allowing identification of infecting species and quantification of parasitemia.

questionList.questionText: A 38-year-old woman comes to the office due to fatty food intolerance.  On examination, her vital signs are normal, and she has mild right upper quadrant abdominal tenderness.  An ultrasonogram of the abdomen reveals multiple gallstones with no evidence of cholecystitis and an ill-defined intrahepatic cyst with a thick wall.  A CT of the abdomen is performed and reveals a well-defined cyst with eggshell calcification.  The patient has no known medical problems.  She does not use recreational drugs and has never had surgery.  The patient has not travelled outside the United States.  She has had 2 pet dogs at home for 10 years.  Her parents emigrated from Peru years ago.  What is the most likely etiology for the intrahepatic cyst in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Echinococcus granulosus

Epidemiology

  • Dog tapeworm (sheep intermediate host)
  • Rural, developing countries (eg, South America, Middle East)
  • Humans are incidental hosts (egg ingestion)

Manifestations

  • Initially asymptomatic (often for years)
  • Liver cyst (most common)
    • Mass effect: RUQ pain, nausea, vomiting, hepatomegaly
    • Rupture: fever, eosinophilia
  • Lung cyst: cough, chest pain, hemoptysis

Diagnosis

  • Large, smooth hydatid cyst often with internal septations on imaging
  • IgG E granulosus serology

Treatment

  • Albendazole
  • Percutaneous therapy (>5 cm or septations)
  • Surgery (if rupture)

RUQ = right upper quadrant.

This patient most likely has a hydatid cyst due to Echinococcus granulosus.  Humans contract the infection from close contact with dogs, which are the definitive host in the tapeworm's lifecycle.  E granulosus can cause unilocular cystic lesions that can occur in any organ (eg, liver, lung, muscle, bone); smaller daughter cysts (with internal septation) may be present.  (Although both E granulosus and E multilocularis can cause cystic lesions of different forms, E multilocularis infection tends to cause multiple lesions and be more symptomatic.)

Most hydatid cysts are diagnosed incidentally when patients are being evaluated for other problems (eg, fatty food intolerance likely from cholelithiasis in this patient).  However, these cysts can cause symptoms due to compression on surrounding tissues.  Imaging techniques and serologic testing can be used for diagnosis.  Ultrasound has excellent sensitivity (~95%) and typically shows a large, smooth hepatic cyst often with daughter cysts (internal septations).   Positive serology for E granulosus IgG corroborates the diagnosis (sensitivity ~95%) and usually obviates the need for percutaneous biopsy.  "Eggshell" calcification of a hepatic cyst on CT scan is highly suggestive of a hydatid cyst.

Small cysts (<5 cm) are typically treated with albendazole; larger or complex cysts usually also require percutaneous therapy or surgery, although there is a risk of anaphylactic shock due to cyst content spillage.

(Choice A)  Patients with amebic liver abscess (most common extraintestinal manifestation of amebiasis) usually have fever and right upper quadrant pain that can develop within weeks of intestinal amebiasis.  Eggshell calcifications on CT scan would be unusual.

(Choice B)  Cysticercosis is due to infection with Taenia solium and generally presents as cysts in the brain or muscle.

(Choice D)  Pyogenic liver abscesses generally develop following surgery, gastrointestinal infection, or acute appendicitis.  Patients typically have extreme pain, high fevers, and leukocytosis.

(Choice E)  Simple hepatic cysts are believed to be congenital.  The pathophysiology is related to fluid secretion by the epithelial lining.  Patients with simple hepatic cysts that cause symptoms usually report dull right upper quadrant pain, abdominal bloating, or early satiety.  However, these cysts will not show calcification on CT scan.

Educational objective:
In humans, hepatic hydatid cysts are due to infection with Echinococcus granulosus.  Dogs are the definitive host.  A cystic hepatic lesion with eggshell calcification is highly suggestive of infection with this organism.

questionList.title: Echinococcosis

questionList.questionText: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to bloody diarrhea.  The patient was previously in good health.  Two weeks ago, he began having mucoid, loose stools that have gradually become more frequent.  For the past week, the stools have been grossly bloody.  The family has just returned from a 4-week trip to Central America to visit extended family.  Temperature is 36.8 C (98.2 F); other vital signs are normal.  The patient appears uncomfortable but nontoxic.  Physical examination shows mild tenderness of the right lower quadrant and active bowel sounds.  No rebound tenderness is present.  There is no enlargement of the liver or spleen.  Stool samples are sent for microbiologic studies.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
Prolonged (≥2 weeks) travelers' diarrhea

Pathogen

Clinical features

Entamoeba
histolytica

  • Bloody/mucoid diarrhea
  • Extraintestinal disease: liver abscess

Giardia

  • Watery/oily, foul-smelling stools
  • Bloating, fat malabsorption, weight loss

Cryptosporidium
or Cystoisospora

  • Watery diarrhea in immunosuppressed patients

Cyclospora

  • Watery diarrhea ± blood
  • Waxing/waning symptoms

This patient has travelers' diarrhea.  When infectious diarrhea is prolonged (≥2 weeks), the causative pathogen is typically parasitic rather than bacterial or viral.  The presence of blood in the stool makes amebiasis due to Entamoeba histolytica infection the most likely diagnosis.

Although Entamoeba infections are often asymptomatic, the trophozoites can lead to progressive intestinal inflammation and eventual destruction of the intestinal mucosa.  Therefore, common clinical findings of amebiasis include prolonged diarrhea (median: 2-3 weeks) that progresses to colitis.  Symptoms of colitis include stools containing blood and mucus, as well as abdominal tenderness, which is often in the right lower quadrant due to cecal inflammation.  Extraintestinal amebiasis most commonly affects the liver and can also lead to right upper quadrant pain.  Fever is uncommon.

Diagnosis is usually made by examination of the stool for E histolytica, either by PCR or enzyme immunoassay antigen testing.  Treatment of amebic colitis is with metronidazole or tinidazole to eliminate trophozoites in extraintestinal tissue, plus an intraluminal agent such as paromomycin for intestinal disease.

(Choice A)  Cryptosporidium causes watery diarrhea, not bloody/mucoid stools.  Although immunocompromised patients may have prolonged (≥2 weeks) diarrhea associated with malabsorption and weight loss, previously healthy patients typically have self-resolving symptoms lasting <2 weeks.

(Choice C)  Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli is the leading cause of traveler's diarrhea and presents as watery diarrhea and crampy abdominal pain after ingestion of contaminated water or food.  Infection is self-limited and typically resolves in <7 days with supportive therapy.  Bloody stools would not be seen.

(Choice D)  Giardia intestinalis often causes prolonged diarrhea in travelers, and patients may have oily or greasy stools due to fat malabsorption.  However, because Giardia is a noninvasive organism, bloody diarrhea does not occur.

(Choice E)  Nontyphoidal Salmonella is a common cause of diarrhea, which may be bloody, but this infection typically resolves within 10 days.  This patient's prolonged symptoms make this diagnosis unlikely.

Educational objective:
Travel-associated diarrhea lasting ≥2 weeks is most commonly parasitic, and Entamoeba histolytica infection should be suspected when stools are bloody.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Amebiasis

questionMappingReferencesList.title: A review of the global burden, new diagnostics, and current therapeutics for amebiasis.
Illness in the returned international traveler.

questionList.questionText: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office due to worsening headache, nausea, and impaired visual acuity.  The symptoms have been intermittent over the past 4 weeks but have worsened over the last 5 days.  She has no known chronic medical history.  The patient emigrated from rural West Africa 7 years ago.  She has a history of eating wild pork meat, which she says is a common practice in her village.  She is sexually active and uses oral contraceptives.  The patient works as an accountant and often volunteers at a hospital on weekends.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, pulse is 68/min, and respirations are 16/min.  BMI is 35 kg/m2.  Neurologic examination reveals impaired visual acuity and papilledema in both eyes.  No other neurologic abnormalities are present.  MRI of the head shows hydrocephalus with a well-defined cystic lesion in the fourth ventricle with a solid component.  Which of the following is the most likely risk factor for the development of this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Neurocysticercosis

Epidemiology

  • Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) eggs
  • Fecal-oral human transmission
  • Central & South America, sub-Saharan Africa, Asia

Manifestations

  • Prolonged incubation (months to years)
  • Seizures
  • ICH (headache, vomiting, AMS)

Diagnosis

  • CT/MRI scans: cysts (hypodense, enhancement/edema, or calcified)
  • T solium serology

Treatment

  • Seizure/ICH management
  • Antiparasitic therapy (albendazole)
  • Corticosteroids

AMS = altered mental status; ICH = intracranial hypertension.

This patient from West Africa has elevated intracranial pressure (eg, nausea, headache, impaired vision, papilledema) due to a cystic lesion in the fourth ventricle.  These findings indicate neurocysticercosis (NCC), a Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) infection endemic to certain regions in sub-Saharan Africa and Central/South America where pigs, including wild boar, have access to human fecal material.

T solium causes 2 distinct illnesses, as follows:

  • Tapeworm infection occurs when humans ingest larvae in undercooked pork.  The larvae mature into adult worms in the digestive tract and secrete eggs into stool.

  • Cysticercosis occurs when humans ingest eggs shed from the stool of human tapeworm carriers or in contaminated food or water.  The eggs hatch in the gastrointestinal tract, invade the bowel wall, and lodge in tissue (eg, brain, muscle, liver).

Cysticercosis typically presents months or years after transmission due to cyst degeneration.  The most common manifestation is an adult-onset seizure due to an intraparenchymal brain lesion.  However, lesions outside the brain parenchyma (eg, eye, spinal cord, ventricle) can occur; when the ventricle is involved, patients often have fluctuating increased intracranial pressure due to intermittent obstruction of cerebral spinal fluid outflow.

Imaging usually reveals ≥1 cystic lesion at various stages of viability; this may include a hypodense lesion with no enhancement (viable), an enhancing lesion with surrounding edema (degenerating), and/or a calcified nodule (nonviable).  Viable or degenerating cysts require treatment with antiparasitic therapy (eg, albendazole) and adjuvant corticosteroids (to limit inflammation as organisms are destroyed).  Eye examination is required in all cases prior to treatment to exclude ocular cysticercosis and limit vision loss from treatment.

(Choice B)  Elevated BMI is a risk factor for idiopathic intracranial hypertension, which causes headache, visual changes, and papilledema.  However, a cystic brain lesion would not be seen on imaging.

(Choice C)  Exposure to the hospital environment increases risk for tuberculosis, which can cause CNS infection.  However, imaging of the head would reveal ring-enhancing lesions with surrounding edema, not a solitary cystic lesion.

(Choice D)  Oral contraception increases risk for venous thromboembolism.  Thrombosis of the cerebral vein or dural venous sinus can increase ICP, but MRI typically reveals a thrombosis, not a cystic lesion.

(Choice E)  Unprotected sexual activity increases risk for HIV, which can lead to opportunistic CNS infections (eg, toxoplasmosis, cryptococcal meningitis).  Although these can cause elevated ICP, they are not associated with a solitary cystic lesion.

Educational objective:
Taenia solium is a pork tapeworm whose eggs cause neurocysticercosis.  Most infections are asymptomatic, but patients can develop seizures or signs of increased intracranial pressure (eg, vomiting, headaches, papilledema) months or years after transmission.  Neuroimaging usually shows ≥1 cystic lesion in various stages of viability.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Neurocysticercosis

answerChoiceList.choice: Consumption of pork meat in her village

questionList.questionText:
A 36-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to a week of progressive right upper quadrant pain, malaise, anorexia, and fever.  Three months ago, he returned from a vacation in Nepal, where he hiked in the mountains.  During his trip, the patient had several self-resolving episodes of diarrhea.  He also had unprotected sexual intercourse with a woman he met during the trip.  He received no prophylactic vaccinations or oral medications prior to travel.  Temperature is 38.5 C (101.3 F), blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 96/min.  Breath sounds are decreased in the right lung base.  The liver is palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin with a tender, smooth edge.  There is no splenomegaly.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Leukocytes13,000/mm3
Neutrophils67%
Eosinophils2%
Lymphocytes31%
Liver function studies
Total bilirubin1.3 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase320 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT)87 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT)99 U/L

Abdominal ultrasonography reveals a small, solitary hypoechoic lesion on the right lobe of the liver.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Entamoeba histolytica

Risk factors

  • Resource-limited regions (contaminated food/water)

Clinical manifestations

  • Most are asymptomatic
  • Colitis: prolonged bloody/mucoid diarrhea
  • Liver abscess: RUQ pain, fever
    • Complications: pleural effusion, rupture into peritoneum/pleural space

Diagnosis

  • Stool PCR/antigen: preferred
  • Stool microscopy: low sensitivity
  • Serology:* useful for isolated liver abscess

Treatment

  • Metronidazole or tinidazole

PLUS

  • Intraluminal antibiotic (eg, paromomycin)

*Does not distinguish between prior & current infection.

RUQ = right upper quadrant.

This patient has fever, right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain, and a hepatic lesion, findings suggestive of liver abscess.  He also has a history of recent travel to a resource-limited country.  This presentation is concerning for amebiasis (infection due to Entamoeba histolytica).

Amebic liver abscesses develop when the ingested protozoan spreads from the colonic mucosa to the liver via the portal vein.  The greater blood supply of the right lobe of the liver compared to the left explains the characteristic finding of a single, subcapsular, low-density lesion in the right lobe.  Patients may have a history of colitis, but extraintestinal disease can occur without concurrent diarrhea or a classic diarrheal history.

Symptoms of amebic liver abscesses are subacute and include fever, hepatomegaly, and RUQ pain that may be referred to the right chest wall or shoulder.  A right-sided sympathetic pleural effusion can be present due to diaphragmatic irritation from the hepatic lesion and is likely the cause of this patient's decreased breath sounds.  Elevations in leukocyte count, alkaline phosphatase, and transaminases are typical.  As with other protozoal infections (eg, giardiasis), peripheral eosinophilia is not a frequent finding (in contrast to many helminthic infections, which can stimulate IL-5 production).

(Choice A)  Inflammation of the liver capsule in gonococcal perihepatitis (Fitz-Hugh–Curtis syndrome) can cause RUQ pain and fever.  However, this is a complication of pelvic inflammatory disease, a condition not seen in men.

(Choice B)  Hepatotropic viruses (eg, hepatitis A) are often acquired while traveling; acute infection can manifest with RUQ pain.  However, jaundice and markedly elevated aminotransferases (often >1,000 U/L) would be expected, and an abscess would not be seen.

(Choice C)  Malaria causes fever and jaundice after travel to a resource-limited country; however, splenomegaly would be expected, fever is cyclical, and hepatic abscesses are not typical.

(Choice D)  Polymicrobial pyogenic (bacterial) abscesses share similar clinical and radiographic features with amebic abscesses but typically occur in patients who are ill-appearing, are elderly, and have comorbidities (eg, diabetes mellitus).  The absence of these findings plus the patient's recent travel make amebiasis more likely.

(Choice F)  Echinococcus can cause a hydatid liver cyst, but patients are usually asymptomatic.  Large (>10 cm) cysts may cause RUQ pain and hepatomegaly, but fever is rare in the absence of cyst rupture, which is not seen on this patient's imaging.  In addition, peripheral eosinophilia would be expected.

Educational objective:
Entamoeba histolytica, a protozoan, can cause colitis or extraintestinal disease (eg, liver abscess) after travel to a resource-limited country.  Amebic liver abscess causes right upper quadrant pain, fever, and a subcapsular lesion in the right lobe.
questionList.subject: Surgery
questionList.title: Liver abscess

questionMappingReferencesList.title: A review of amoebic liver abscess for clinicians in a nonendemic setting.
Amebic liver abscess.

questionList.questionText: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the office for evaluation of anal pruritus.  A month ago, the patient went on a weekend camping trip with a group of friends.  During the weekend, they learned to swim in the lake and stayed together in a log cabin.  After returning home, the patient began to have increasing anal pruritus that is most severe at night.  He has continued to have a healthy appetite and has had no vomiting or diarrhea.  The patient has no chronic medical conditions, takes no daily medications, and has no known allergies.  Vital signs are normal.  Physical examination shows a well-appearing patient in no apparent distress.  Skin examination is normal.  The lungs are clear to auscultation, and the abdomen is soft and nondistended.  Inspection of the anus shows mild perianal erythema with multiple excoriations, but no induration, fluctuance, or fissures.  Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm)

Pathogenesis

  • Transmission via ingestion of eggs
  • Larvae develop into adult worms in the intestines
  • Female worms migrate to the perianal region at night & deposit eggs

Findings

  • Nocturnal perianal pruritus → perianal erythema/excoriations*

Diagnosis

  • Mobile worms visualized near anal verge
  • Tape test: eggs visualized under microscopic examination

Treatment**

  • Albendazole, mebendazole, or pyrantel pamoate
  • Administered to patient & household contacts, then repeated in 2 weeks

*Worm migration to vulvar region may also cause symptoms of vulvovaginitis (eg, vulvar itching & erythema).

**Empiric treatment (ie, without visualization of eggs/worms) can be performed for those with classic findings.

This patient most likely has a pinworm infection (enterobiasis), a common helminthic infection that frequently affects school-age children.  The life cycle of Enterobius vermicularis, a nematode, occurs within the gastrointestinal tract.  Transmission occurs via ingestion of eggs, typically due to autoinoculation from contaminated hands.  The larvae develop to adult worms within the small intestine.  At night, female worms migrate through the rectum and deposit eggs in the perianal region, resulting in nocturnal perianal pruritus with associated perianal erythema and excoriations.  Other symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and vulvovaginitis.

Diagnosis is based on visualization of adult worms or eggs.  Common diagnostic tests include the "scotch tape test" or "pinworm paddle test", in which the Enterobius eggs adhere to the adhesive surface and are visualized under microscopy.  Stool cultures are of limited value as eggs are rarely passed in the stool.  Treatment is with either pyrantel pamoate or albendazole; the patient and all household contacts should be treated because the infection is highly contagious.

(Choice A)  Clotrimazole is used to treat Candida albicans infections, which can involve the perianal area and cause pruritus ani.  Candida infections typically present with a beefy-red rash within skin folds (eg, intertrigo) and associated satellite lesions, not seen in this patient.

(Choice B)  Ivermectin is the first-line treatment for strongyloidiasis, which presents with urticaria, abdominal pain, and respiratory problems (eg, dry cough, dyspnea, wheezing).  Onchocerciasis ("river blindness") causes ocular lesions and dermatitis and is also treated with ivermectin.

(Choice C)  Metronidazole is used for protozoan infections such as amebiasis (eg, acute dysentery, liver abscess) and trichomoniasis (eg, green-yellow, frothy, malodorous discharge) as well as for anaerobic intraabdominal infections (eg, diverticulitis, peritonitis, cholangitis, abscess).  It is not used for enterobiasis.

(Choice D)  Permethrin is the first-line treatment for scabies, which causes intense pruritis that is often worse at night; however, scabies more commonly affects the extremities and has associated papules and burrows, making this diagnosis unlikely.

(Choice E)  Praziquantel is used to treat schistosomiasis, which can present as pruritus after swimming in fresh water; however, patients initially have an urticarial rash on the lower legs or feet, followed several weeks later with diarrhea, weight loss, and right upper quadrant pain.

Educational objective:
Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) infection is highly contagious and manifests as nocturnal perianal pruritus.  First-line treatment is with pyrantel pamoate or albendazole.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Intestinal helminth parasites

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Soil-transmitted helminth infections: ascariasis, trichuriasis, and hookworm.

questionList.questionText: A 29-year-old man comes to the office due to 10 days of fatigue and copious watery diarrhea.  He has had no fever, tenesmus, vomiting, or blood or mucus in the stool.  The patient returned a week ago from a 3-week trip to Eastern Europe.  During this trip, he spent a lot of time hiking and swimming in local lakes and streams.  He has no chronic medical conditions and takes no medications.  The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.  Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 120/74 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 15/min.  Cardiopulmonary auscultation is normal.  The abdomen is soft and nontender with increased bowel sounds and no organomegaly.  Stool testing is negative for leukocytes and fecal occult blood.  Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
Cryptosporidiosis

Epidemiology

  • Fecal-oral transmission (eg, contaminated water, animal contact)
  • Risk factors: immunosuppression (eg, AIDS, transplant recipient)

Clinical manifestations

  • Immunocompetent: self-resolving, watery (noninflammatory) diarrhea <2 weeks
  • Immunosuppressed:
    • Prolonged, severe diarrhea with weight loss/malabsorption
    • Biliary disease (eg, cholecystitis, cholangitis)

Diagnosis

  • Stool PCR testing
  • Stool microscopy: acid-fast staining oocysts or immunofluorescent assay
  • Intestinal biopsy: organisms on mucosal brush border

Treatment

  • Immunocompetent: supportive care only
  • Immunocompromised*: nitazoxanide

*Patients with HIV should be started on antiretroviral therapy first & treated with antimicrobial therapy only if symptoms persist.

This patient who recently returned from a resource-limited region has travelers' diarrhea.  Although bacterial and viral pathogens are the most common causes of travelers' diarrhea, parasitic organisms such as Cryptosporidium parvum, Cyclospora, and Giardia are responsible for most cases of prolonged, profuse, watery diarrhea.

C parvum is an intracellular protozoan most commonly transmitted via ingestion of contaminated water (eg, drinking, swimming).  Oocysts release sporozoites that attach to intestinal epithelial cells, resulting in altered villous architecture.  Although a minority of patients remain asymptomatic, most develop mild or profuse, watery, noninflammatory (ie, negative fecal leukocytes or blood) diarrhea.  Malaise, nausea, crampy abdominal pain, and low-grade fever may also occur.

Stool PCR testing or microscopy with acid-fast staining is usually diagnostic; routine stool ova and parasite testing does not identify Cryptosporidium.  Infection with C parvum is typically associated with immunocompromise (eg, AIDS); such patients are at risk for severe, prolonged disease.  However, the organism is also among the most common enteric pathogens globally, and outbreaks related to contaminated water affect immunocompetent hosts, who typically have spontaneous resolution of symptoms within 10-14 days.

(Choice A)  Clostridioides difficile usually causes watery diarrhea with positive fecal leukocytes and occult blood.  Moreover, this patient lacks risk factors for this infection, including recent hospitalization or antibiotic exposure.

(Choices C and D)  Gastroenteritis due to invasive organisms such as Entamoeba histolytica (which can cause prolonged symptoms) and Shigella flexneri, typically presents with bloody or mucoid diarrhea.  In addition, positive fecal blood and leukocytes would be expected.

(Choice E)  Strongyloides stercoralis is a helminth that can cause mild gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea, but skin (eg, pruritic streaking) and respiratory (eg, cough) symptoms would be expected.  Acute onset of isolated profuse watery diarrhea is not seen.

Educational objective:
Cryptosporidium causes watery, noninflammatory diarrhea that self-resolves in immunocompetent patients within 10-14 days; immunocompromised patients are at risk for prolonged, severe disease.  This infection is most commonly acquired after travel to resource-limited regions due to ingestion of contaminated water.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Cryptosporidiosis

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Cryptosporidium infection in solid organ transplantation.
Traveler's diarrhea.

questionList.questionText:
A 4-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department via ambulance after a seizure at home.  The patient was born at 35 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery to a gravida 3 para 3 woman.  The pregnancy was complicated by limited prenatal care and polysubstance use disorder.  The patient is currently cared for by a foster family.  The foster mother says that she was bottle feeding when the patient's extremities suddenly started shaking.  She was unresponsive for 1-2 minutes.  On examination, the patient is sleeping but arouses with examination.  Height and weight are at the 25th percentile, and head circumference is at the 97th percentile for age.  Retinal examination reveals evidence of acute and chronic retinal inflammation and is shown in the image below:

Heart and lung sounds are normal.  The abdomen is soft with moderate hepatosplenomegaly.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
questionList.explanationText:
Congenital toxoplasmosis

Maternal
risk factors

  • Raw or undercooked meat
  • Unwashed produce (ie, contaminated soil)
  • Handling of cat feces

Clinical
features

  • Classic triad:
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Diffuse intracranial calcifications
    • Hydrocephalus
  • Microcephaly (brain atrophy) or macrocephaly (severe hydrocephalus)
  • Seizures
  • Nonspecific findings: jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, rash, growth restriction

Diagnosis

  • Toxoplasma serology or PCR

Treatment

  • Pyrimethamine, sulfadiazine, folinic acid
PCR = polymerase chain reaction.

This infant with seizures and hepatosplenomegaly has chorioretinitis, or inflammation and scarring of the retina and choroid, on funduscopic examination.  Chorioretinitis is commonly associated with congenital infections and is a long-term sequela of chronic infection that can lead to permanent vision loss.

The predominant pathogens associated with chorioretinitis include Toxoplasma gondii (most common) and cytomegalovirus (CMV), both of which cause intrauterine infection due to transplacental transmission from an infected mother.  Hepatosplenomegaly due to reticuloendothelial activation from chronic infection is a nonspecific finding that can also occur with either pathogen, and other late manifestations can include seizures and intellectual disability.  Although both T gondii and CMV are associated with microcephaly, congenital toxoplasmosis can also cause macrocephaly (eg, head circumference at 97th percentile in this patient) due to severe hydrocephalus; this makes Toxoplasma the most likely cause of this patient's presentation.

Diagnosis is confirmed by serology (ie, Toxoplasma IgA or IgM) or PCR testing.  Treatment of congenital toxoplasmosis is with pyrimethamine, sulfadiazine, and folinic acid—a multidrug regimen that reduces the parasite burden in the CNS and helps to prevent progression of retinal disease.

(Choice A)  Child abuse should be suspected in any infant with retinal hemorrhages, which are seen as areas of blood extravasation on retinal examination, and seizure may occur due to intracranial bleeding.  However, this patient's retinal findings are not consistent with hemorrhage.

(Choice B)  Seizure may be the initial presentation of an intracranial tumor in a child, and hepatosplenomegaly may also occur.  Funduscopic examination may reveal optic disc edema due to increased intracranial pressure; retinal scarring would not be present.

(Choice D)  Infants born to mothers with substance abuse disorders during pregnancy are at risk for neonatal abstinence syndrome, which presents in the first week of life with irritability, poor feeding, sneezing, diarrhea, and in severe cases, seizures.  Symptoms can last up to a month in rare cases but would not be present or develop at age 4 months.  In addition, hepatosplenomegaly and retinitis are not features of this condition.

(Choice E)  Niemann-Pick disease is a lipid storage disorder associated with hepatosplenomegaly and neurodegeneration in infancy.  Seizures may occur, but retinal findings include a cherry-red macula, not retinal inflammation and scarring.

Educational objective:
Chorioretinitis, or inflammation and scarring of the retina and choroid, is typically caused by chronic infection (eg, Toxoplasma gondii, cytomegalovirus).  Congenital toxoplasmosis is the most common etiology, and additional findings include macrocephaly (due to hydrocephalus), hepatosplenomegaly, and seizures.

questionList.title: Toxoplasmosis

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Congenital central toxoplasmic chorioretinitis  case study.
Toxoplasmosis.

questionList.questionText:
A 26-year-old man comes to the clinic due to a 2-week history of persistent abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant, low-grade fever, and anorexia.  The patient recently emigrated from Mexico, where he worked as a mechanic.  For several days 3 months ago, he had bloody diarrhea, which resolved spontaneously.  He takes no medications or herbal preparations.  The patient has had no other travel, exposure to animals, or sick contacts.  Temperature is 38.7 C (101.7 F), blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg, pulse is 82/min, and respirations are 14/min.  Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant but is otherwise unremarkable.  There is no jaundice.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
Hemoglobin14.2 g/dL
Platelets310,000/mm3
Leukocytes11,800/mm3
Neutrophils65%
Eosinophils1%
Lymphocytes30%
Monocytes4%
Liver function test
Alkaline phosphatase300 U/L

CT scan of the abdomen reveals a 2 × 3 cm cystic lesion in the right lobe of the liver.  Blood cultures are obtained.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Entamoeba histolytica

Risk factors

  • Resource-limited regions (contaminated food/water)

Clinical manifestations

  • Most are asymptomatic
  • Colitis: prolonged bloody/mucoid diarrhea
  • Liver abscess: RUQ pain, fever
    • Complications: pleural effusion, rupture into peritoneum/pleural space

Diagnosis

  • Stool PCR/antigen: preferred
  • Stool microscopy: low sensitivity
  • Serology:* useful for isolated liver abscess

Treatment

  • Metronidazole or tinidazole

PLUS

  • Intraluminal antibiotic (eg, paromomycin)

*Does not distinguish between prior & current infection.

RUQ = right upper quadrant.

This patient has fever, right upper quadrant pain, and a cystic hepatic lesion, findings worrisome for a liver abscess.  With the history of bloody diarrhea and recent emigration from a resource-limited country, this presentation suggests Entamoeba histolytica infection (amebiasis), a protozoan infection typically acquired via contamined food or water.

E histolytica infection is usually asymptomatic but can result in amebic colitis (eg, bloody diarrhea) or extraintestinal disease via hematogenous spread to the liver, lungs, or brain.  The most common extraintestinal manifestation is a liver abscess, which may present weeks to months after initial infection.  Like other causes of liver abscess (eg, bacterial), amebic liver abscesses cause fever, right upper quadrant pain, and elevated liver enzymes, particularly alkaline phosphatase.  Leukocytosis, often without left shift, may be present.  Eosinophilia, usually seen in helminthic (rather than protozoal) infections, is not characteristic.  Concurrent diarrhea is usually absent, but a prior history of bloody stools may be elicited.

In patients in whom amebiasis is suspected and who have active diarrhea, stool antigen or PCR testing is preferred (sensitive and specific).  Stool microscopy (eg, ova and parasites) looking for cysts and trophozoites is sometimes the only diagnostic tool available but has low sensitivity, often requires multiple specimens, and is operator dependent (Choice B).  In contrast, in patients such as this one with a liver abscess and no concurrent diarrhea, preferred diagnostic testing is serology, although it cannot differentiate between prior and current infection.

(Choices A and C)  Percutaneous aspiration/drainage and intravenous antibiotics (eg, ceftriaxone) are treatments for bacterial liver abscesses.  These typically occur in the setting of biliary infection or hematogenous spread of intraabdominal infections in elderly patients with underlying comorbidities (eg, diabetes mellitus); patients are usually jaundiced and ill-appearing.  In contrast, management of amebic liver abscesses is an oral tissue agent (eg, metronidazole) and a luminal agent (ie, paromomycin) to eradicate intestinal colonization.  Drainage has not been shown to improve outcomes compared to medical therapy and is reserved for those whose condition fails to improve with initial therapy or who have large (>10 cm) lesions at risk of imminent rupture.

(Choice E)  Surgical resection may be indicated for hepatic cysts caused by Echinococcus; however, small cysts (<10 cm) are typically asymptomatic, and eosinophilia would be expected.

Educational objective:
Entamoeba histolytica infection should be considered in patients with a liver abscess (eg, fever, right upper quadrant pain, cystic hepatic lesion) who have traveled in a resource-limited country; a prior history of bloody diarrhea is common.  Serologic testing is the preferred diagnostic modality in the absence of concurrent diarrhea.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Liver abscess

answerChoiceList.choice: Examination of the stool for ova and parasites

questionMappingReferencesList.title: A review of amoebic liver abscess for clinicians in a nonendemic setting.
Amebic liver abscess.

questionList.questionText:
A 31-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his friends due to 2 weeks of headaches and progressive confusion.  His friends note that he has also been aggressive and inappropriately suspicious, which is not typical for him.  The patient is a flight attendant and frequently works on international flights.  He has a history of HIV infection and sometimes skips antiretroviral therapy when he travels.  His friends are unsure if he takes other prophylactic medications.  Temperature is 38.6 C (101.5 F), blood pressure is 118/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 102/min.  The patient appears unkempt and is disoriented.  Neurologic examination shows ataxia and right-sided hemiparesis.  Brain MRI findings are shown in the image below.

Which of the following would have most likely prevented this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient with HIV has neurologic symptoms (headache, confusion, focal deficits), fever, and evidence of ring-enhancing lesions on MRI, raising strong suspicion for toxoplasmosis.  Most cases occur due to reactivation of Toxoplasma gondii, a widely prevalent intracellular protozoan, due to severe deficits in cell-mediated immunity (eg, AIDS with CD4 counts <100/mm3).

Primary prophylaxis against toxoplasmosis is highly effective at preventing the condition in those with advanced AIDS.  Therefore, all patients with HIV undergo laboratory evaluation (T gondii IgG testing) for exposure; those with positive serology who have a CD4 count <100/mm3 require primary prophylaxis with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX), which reduces the risk of toxoplasmosis to 0%-2%.

Patients on antiretroviral treatment can usually discontinue TMP-SMX prophylaxis when their CD4 count is >200/mm3 for 3 months (and there is adequate viral suppression).  TMP-SMX is also used for primary prophylaxis against Pneumocystis pneumonia for those with a CD4 count <200/mm3.

(Choice A)  Acyclovir is used to treat the herpes simplex virus (HSV).  HSV encephalitis often causes focal neurologic findings and confusion, but an MRI usually reveals unilateral temporal lobe lesions (not widespread ring-enhancing lesions).  Acyclovir primary prophylaxis is not generally recommended in patients with AIDS, but secondary prophylaxis (to prevent frequent flares) is sometimes given.

(Choice B)  Albendazole can be used for treatment of neurocysticercosis, which most commonly causes seizures and leads to cystic, enhancing, or calcified lesions on neuroimaging.  Albendazole is not typically used as a primary preventive agent.

(Choice C)  Fluconazole is occasionally used for primary prophylaxis against coccidioidomycosis (for those in endemic areas with newly converted serology).  Coccidioidomycosis primarily manifests with pulmonary disease but occasionally causes meningitis.  However, multiple ring-enhancing lesions would be atypical.  Fluconazole is also used as secondary prophylaxis (suppressive therapy) for those with a history of cryptococcal meningitis (when CD4 count is still low); fluconazole is not used as primary prophylaxis for Cryptococcus, and Cryptococcus does not typically cause ring-enhancing brain lesions.

(Choice D)  Ganciclovir can be used to treat cytomegalovirus (CMV) but is not typically used for primary prophylaxis in patients with AIDS.  It is used for primary prophylaxis against CMV in some patients with solid organ transplantation.

Educational objective:
Toxoplasmosis is a common opportunistic infection in patients with AIDS who have CD4 counts <100/mm3.  Primary prophylaxis with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) prevents active infection; TMP-SMX is generally given to patients with AIDS who have CD4 counts <100/mm3 and positive Toxoplasma gondii IgG serology.  TMP-SMX is also effective in preventing Pneumocystis pneumonia.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Toxoplasmosis

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Prevention and treatment of opportunistic infections in HIV-infected adults and adolescents: updated guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, National Institutes of Health, and HIV Medicine Association of the Infectious Diseases Society of America.

questionList.questionText: A 28-year-old man comes to the office due to abnormal movements of his arm and face over the last week.  The patient has had 1- to 2-minute episodes of jerking and twitching of the left arm and left side of the face.  He has also had daily headaches for a few weeks that are often associated with nausea.  The patient was recently diagnosed with HIV and started antiretroviral therapy 2 months ago.  At that time, his CD4 count was 46/mm3.  He has a history of intravenous heroin use but recently started a methadone program.  Temperature is 37.8 C (100 F), blood pressure is 124/82 mm Hg, and pulse is 76/min.  Cardiopulmonary examination is normal with no murmur.  Left arm motor strength is 4/5, and deep tendon reflexes are 3+.  A MRI of the brain reveals several ring-enhancing lesions at the gray-white matter junction and basal ganglia.  Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Toxoplasma encephalitis

Symptoms

  • Headache
  • Confusion
  • Fever
  • Focal neurologic deficits/seizures

Diagnosis

  • AIDS with CD4+ count <100/mm3
  • Positive Toxoplasma gondii IgG
  • Multiple ring-enhancing brain lesions (MRI)

Treatment

  • Sulfadiazine & pyrimethamine (plus leucovorin)
  • Antiretroviral initiation within 2 weeks
  • Prophylaxis: TMP-SMX (CD4+ count <100/mm3)

TMP-SMX = trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

Toxoplasmosis is caused by the reactivation of Toxoplasma gondii, an intracellular protozoan that lies dormant in infected individuals and rarely reemerges unless there are significant deficits in cell-mediated immunity.  Patients with advanced AIDS who have CD4 counts <100/mm3 are at greatest risk (as high as 30%).  Although toxoplasmosis may affect multiple organ systems (eg, pulmonary, ocular), encephalitis is by far the most common manifestation.

Patients with toxoplasmic encephalitis usually develop headaches, focal neurologic deficits, altered mental status, and fever.  Laboratory studies may be normal, but MRI of the brain usually reveals multiple ring-enhancing lesions (with a preference for the basal ganglia).  There is no reliable test for toxoplasmic encephalitis.  The diagnosis is generally made by the presence of suspicious clinical symptoms, positive T gondii IgG serology, and characteristic central nervous system findings on MRI.  Treatment with several weeks of sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine plus leucovorin (to prevent hematologic side effects) is required.  Antiretroviral therapy should be initiated within 2 weeks of toxoplasmosis treatment (once patients are clearly tolerating toxoplasma therapy) for those not already on antiretroviral treatment.

(Choice A)  Albendazole is used to treat neurocysticercosis, which is associated with consumption of Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) eggs in endemic areas (eg, Central and South America).  Neurocysticercosis tends to cause seizures, and an MRI of the brain usually reveals a mixture of enhancing, nonenhancing, and calcified lesions (depending on the stage of the cyst).  In this patient with advanced HIV, no history of travel, and multiple ring-enhancing lesions (including on the basal ganglia), toxoplasmosis is more likely.

(Choice B)  Amphotericin B and flucytosine are used to treat cryptococcal meningitis.  Cryptococcal infections tend to present with fever, malaise, and headaches; ring-enhancing lesions on MRI would be atypical.

(Choice C)  A brain biopsy should be considered only in patients not responding to initial treatment because it is invasive and associated with a high risk for complications.  Toxoplasmosis is treated presumptively in patients with characteristic clinical, serologic, and MRI findings.

(Choice E)  Vancomycin and ceftriaxone are used empirically for bacterial meningitis.  Bacterial meningitis typically presents acutely (<1 day) with fever, severe headache, and altered mental status.  Nuchal rigidity may also be present.  Enhancing lesions are uncommon.

Educational objective:
Toxoplasmosis causes headache, fever, focal neurologic deficits, and altered mental status in patients with advanced AIDS (CD4 count <100/mm3).  An MRI of the brain reveals multiple ring-enhancing lesions.  Treatment is with sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Toxoplasmosis

questionList.questionText: A 1-day-old boy is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit due to macrocephaly and jaundice.  The patient was born by spontaneous vaginal delivery at 41 weeks gestation to a 38-year-old woman, gravida 4 para 3 (2 live vaginal births and a first-trimester miscarriage), who had consistent prenatal care.  The mother traveled to central Africa during the first trimester.  While there, she developed fever that lasted 2 weeks along with swollen lymph nodes and muscle aches that resolved spontaneously.  The patient's weight and length are at the 25th percentile; head circumference is above the 97th percentile.  Vital signs are normal.  Diffuse jaundice is noted on examination.  The liver is palpable 4 cm below the costal margin.  Heart and lung sounds are normal on auscultation.  CT scan of the head reveals hydrocephalus and diffuse intracranial calcifications.  Laboratory results include total bilirubin 7.2 mg/dL and direct bilirubin 5.5 mg/dL.  Which of the following maternal exposures most likely resulted in this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Congenital toxoplasmosis vs congenital cytomegalovirus

Toxoplasmosis

CMV

Pathogenesis

  • Maternal consumption of undercooked meat or inadvertent ingestion of cat feces
  • Maternal contact with infected bodily fluids (eg, saliva)

Classic
features*

  • Chorioretinitis
  • Diffuse intracranial calcifications
  • Macrocephaly (ie, hydrocephalus) or microcephaly
  • Seizures
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Periventricular intracranial calcifications
  • Microcephaly
  • Sensorineural hearing loss

Diagnosis

  • Toxoplasma serology or PCR
  • Urine or saliva CMV PCR

Treatment

  • Pyrimethamine, sulfadiazine, folinic acid
  • Ganciclovir or valganciclovir if symptomatic

*Nonspecific features of congenital infections include jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, rash & growth restriction.

CMV = cytomegalovirus.

This infant has features of congenital toxoplasmosis due to transplacental transmission of Toxoplasma gondii.  Characteristic findings in a symptomatic infant include hydrocephalus and diffuse intracranial calcifications; chorioretinitis is also frequently seen.  Although toxoplasmosis is often associated with microcephaly due to brain atrophy, hydrocephalus can lead to macrocephaly in some patients, as seen in this neonate.  Nonspecific findings of congenital infection include jaundice, cholestasis, hyperbilirubinemia, and hepatomegaly.

The pathogenesis of toxoplasmosis, which is prevalent in warm, humid environments (eg, central Africa), begins with shedding of protozoan oocysts in the feces of infected cats (definitive hosts).  The oocysts contaminate soil and water and are ingested by other animals.  Pregnant women acquire the infection by inadvertent ingestion of cat feces (eg, contaminated kitty litter) or consumption of unwashed produce or raw or undercooked meat from infected animals.

Maternal infection may be asymptomatic or cause a self-resolving illness with fever, myalgias, lymphadenopathy, and/or rash.  First-trimester infection is more likely to result in severe, symptomatic neonatal infection.

(Choice A)  Syphilis, hepatitis B, and HIV are common congenital infections that can be transmitted sexually.  None of these infections is associated with the type of intracranial lesion seen in this patient.

(Choice B)  A pregnant woman can transmit parvovirus or rubella infection to the fetus after exposure to infected respiratory droplets.  Unlike congenital toxoplasmosis, congenital parvovirus causes severe fetal anemia (eg, pallor, tachycardia) and hydrops fetalis (eg, edema, pleural/pericardial effusions).  Although congenital rubella can also cause hepatomegaly and jaundice, the classic features of cataracts, sensorineural hearing loss, and congenital heart disease would be expected.  Intracranial calcifications are not seen in either parvovirus or rubella.

(Choice C)  Zika virus and malaria are prevalent in Africa and could have been acquired by the mother via mosquito bite.  Although congenital Zika virus can cause intracranial calcifications, it is marked by severe microcephaly (not macrocephaly).  Congenital malaria typically presents with fever, anemia, and splenomegaly, not intracranial calcifications.

(Choice D)  Saliva is the most common source of cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.  In contrast to T gondii infection, in which diffuse intracranial calcifications are caused by direct parenchymal infection, CMV is associated with periventricular calcifications due to germinal matrix bleeds.  In addition, CMV causes microcephaly.

Educational objective:
Congenital toxoplasmosis classically presents with hydrocephalus and diffuse intracranial calcifications.  Maternal acquisition of toxoplasmosis is due most commonly to ingestion of cat feces or undercooked meat from animals infected with Toxoplasma gondii.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Toxoplasmosis

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Toxoplasmosis in the fetus and newborn: an update on prevalence, diagnosis and treatment.

questionList.questionText:
A 22-year-old student comes to the office due to 4 days of fever, double vision, and painful swelling around his eyes.  He also has significant muscle pain in his neck and jaw muscles.  Two weeks ago, the patient returned from a trip to central Mexico.  One week after his return, he developed abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.  These symptoms resolved spontaneously.  He has a history of intravenous drug use and recently completed a drug rehabilitation program.  Temperature is 38.3 C (101 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 92/min, and respirations are 14/min.  Physical examination shows subungual splinter hemorrhages, periorbital edema, and chemosis.  Lungs are clear to auscultation.  Cardiac examination shows no murmurs.  The abdomen is soft and nontender without organomegaly.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin13.0 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume85 µm3
Platelets228,000/mm3
Leukocytes10,500/mm3
    Neutrophils56%
    Eosinophils21%
    Lymphocytes23%
Creatine kinase220 U/L

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Clinical features of trichinellosis

Epidemiology
& life cycle

  • Ingestion of undercooked meat (usually pork)
  • More endemic in Mexico, China, Thailand, parts of central Europe & Argentina
  • Gastric acid releases larvae (within 1st week of ingestion) that invade the small intestine & develop into worms
  • Female worms release larvae (up to 4 weeks later) that migrate & encyst in striated muscle

Clinical
presentation

Intestinal stage (within a week of ingestion)

  • Can be asymptomatic or include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting & diarrhea
 

Muscle stage (up to 4 weeks after ingestion)

  • Myositis
  • Fever, subungual splinter hemorrhages
  • Periorbital edema
  • Eosinophilia (usually >20%) with possible elevated creatine kinase & leukocytosis

This patient's presentation suggests trichinellosis (also known as trichinosis), a parasitic infection caused by the roundworm Trichinella.  The organism is prevalent worldwide, but the infection is more common in Mexico, China, Thailand, parts of central Europe, and Argentina.  Infection usually occurs after eating undercooked or raw meat (usually pork) containing encysted Trichinella larvae.  Within the first week of ingestion, gastric acid releases the encysted larvae.  The larvae invade the small intestine and develop into worms (intestinal stage).  Female worms can release new larvae (up to 4 weeks later) that migrate and encyst into striated muscle (muscle stage).

During the intestinal stage, patients can be asymptomatic or develop abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.  During the muscle stage, patients may develop local or systemic findings due to larval migration into various tissues; these include fever, subungual splinter hemorrhages, conjunctival and retinal hemorrhages, periorbital edema, and chemosis.  Larvae entering the muscle can cause pain, tenderness, swelling, and weakness (eg, neck, arms, shoulders).  Laboratory studies show eosinophilia (usually >20%), the hallmark of the disease.  Other findings include possible elevated creatine kinase and leukocytosis.  Diagnosis is suspected clinically with the characteristic triad of periorbital edema, myositis, and eosinophilia.  Severe disease can involve the heart, lungs, and central nervous system.

Mild infections are typically self-limited; severe infections require antiparasitic therapy (eg, mebendazole, albendazole) with corticosteroids.

(Choice A)  Ascariasis can also present with intestinal symptoms and eosinophilia, but more often has a lung phase with nonproductive cough followed by an asymptomatic intestinal phase.  Ascariasis can also present with the worms obstructing the small bowel or bile ducts.  This patient's triad of periorbital edema, myositis, and eosinophilia is more consistent with trichinellosis.

(Choice B)  Dengue fever can present with fever, headache, and significant myalgia and arthralgias (with some patients developing hemorrhagic dengue fever with significant hemorrhage in the skin or nose).  However, dengue fever does not usually cause marked eosinophilia, and it is classically associated with retro-orbital pain and rash.

(Choice C)  Acute giardiasis can present with diarrhea (can be steatorrhea), flatulence, abdominal cramps, weight loss, and nausea.  However, giardia usually does not cause the significant myalgias or eosinophilia seen in this patient.

(Choice D)  Infective endocarditis can present with fever, cardiac murmur, and embolic phenomenon (eg, subungual splinter hemorrhages).  Although this patient's drug use history can suggest endocarditis, this disorder usually does not cause significant eosinophilia or periorbital edema.  Subungual splinter hemorrhages are classically associated with endocarditis but are also seen with trichinellosis (due to larval migration).

(Choice F)  Typhoid fever usually presents in a progressive manner with fever in the 1st week of illness, abdominal pain and salmon-colored rash in the 2nd week, and hepatosplenomegaly with abdominal complications (eg, intestinal bleeding, perforation) during the 3rd week.  However, it does not cause significant eosinophilia.

Educational objective:
Trichinellosis typically presents with gastrointestinal complaints (eg, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting) followed by the characteristic triad of periorbital edema, myositis, and eosinophilia (hallmark of the disease).  Other findings include fever, subungual splinter hemorrhages, and conjunctival or retinal hemorrhages.
