questionList.title: Trichinellosis

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Epidemiology, diagnosis, treatment, and control of trichinellosis.

questionList.questionText: A 19-year-old man comes to the office prior to leaving for a trip to India for a student exchange program.  He has no significant medical history and is up to date with immunizations.  Physical examination is normal.  The patient is advised to consume bottled water and avoid raw foods.  Hepatitis A and typhoid vaccinations and prescriptions for travelers' diarrhea are provided.  Which of the following is the best recommendation for malaria prevention in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Malaria prevention

High-risk groups

  • Travelers new to endemic regions
  • Travelers returning to endemic region after long absence
  • Pregnant women

Mosquito bite
avoidance

  • Avoid being outside from dusk → dawn
  • Cover skin with clothing
  • Wear insect repellant
  • Use insecticide-treated bed nets
  • Sleep in screened/air-conditioned rooms

Chemoprophylaxis

  • Atovaquone-proguanil
  • Mefloquine
  • Doxycycline
  • Tafenoquine

Individuals traveling to malaria-endemic regions are at high risk for acquiring the infection, but risk differs based on the geographic location visited, altitude, accommodation type (eg, open air vs air conditioned), season, and duration of travel.  All individuals traveling to endemic regions should be advised to prevent mosquito bites with protective clothing, insect repellent, and insecticide-treated bed netting.  In addition, chemoprophylaxis is particularly important for individuals with no partial immunity to malaria, namely those new to an endemic region or returning after a long absence.

Travelers to India generally require chemoprophylaxis due to a high prevalence of both Plasmodium falciparum and Plasmodium vivax throughout most of the country.  Because chloroquine resistance is common in India, travelers are usually given chemoprophylaxis with atovaquone-proguanil, doxycycline, tafenoquine, or mefloquine.  The agent should be taken:

  • before travel to ensure adequate levels on arrival
  • during the stay, with no interruptions, to maximize continuous prophylaxis
  • after returning from the trip to provide protection from merozoites released from the liver over 1-4 weeks. 

Chemoprophylaxis can also be started some time prior to travel in order to address patient concerns about side effects (as it allows time to switch agents if needed).

For example, treatment with mefloquine (a weekly medication) should be initiated ≥2 weeks prior to travel, continued during the stay, and discontinued 4 weeks after returning.  Neuropsychiatric adverse effects (eg, anxiety, depression) occur in approximately 5% of patients and should prompt a change to another medication.

(Choice A)  This patient is traveling to a malaria-endemic country for a prolonged period.  Because he is presumably new to the region (on a student exchange program), he likely has no partial immunity against the organism and is at high risk for severe infection.  Therefore, chemoprophylaxis is recommended.  Malaria can be fatal and requires prompt treatment, typically with an agent different from the one used for chemoprophylaxis.

(Choices B and C)  Most chemoprophylaxis regimens require the initiation of treatment at least a few days prior to travel, continuation during travel, and discontinuation several days or weeks after returning.  This provides protection for the first few days of arrival, during the stay, and on return.

Educational objective:
Malaria chemoprophylaxis is recommended for most travelers visiting malaria-endemic countries.  In areas with high rates of chloroquine resistance, patients take atovaquone-proguanil, doxycycline, tafenoquine, or mefloquine before, during, and after their trip.  Measures for avoiding mosquito bites (eg, protective clothing, insecticide, insecticide-treated bed netting) should also be recommended.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Malaria

answerChoiceList.choice: No No No
No Yes No
Yes Yes No
Yes Yes Yes

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Prevention of malaria in travelers.

questionList.answerHeader: Initiate chemoprophylaxis prior to travelTake chemoprophylaxis during travelContinue chemoprophylaxis for a period after return from travel

questionList.questionText: A 34-year-old man comes to the office due to severe diarrhea and light-headedness.  The diarrhea started approximately 10 days ago and is associated with malaise, nausea, bloating, and upper abdominal cramps.  Since then, the patient has had 8-10 watery, nonbloody stools daily and believes he has lost weight.  He has a history of HIV infection and has been adherent with antiretroviral therapy.  The patient's CD4 count was 520/mm3 last month.  He recently started working at a cattle breeding farm.  Temperature is 38 C (100 F), blood pressure is 108/72 mm Hg, and pulse is 104/min.  BMI is 18 kg/m2.  Mucous membranes are dry.  Bowel sounds are increased.  The stool is brown, and testing is negative for occult blood and leukocytes.  Which of the following is the most likely pathogen responsible for this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Cryptosporidiosis

Epidemiology

  • Fecal-oral transmission (eg, contaminated water, animal contact)
  • Risk factors: immunosuppression (eg, AIDS, transplant recipient)

Clinical manifestations

  • Immunocompetent: self-resolving, watery (noninflammatory) diarrhea <2 weeks
  • Immunosuppressed:
    • Prolonged, severe diarrhea with weight loss/malabsorption
    • Biliary disease (eg, cholecystitis, cholangitis)

Diagnosis

  • Stool PCR testing
  • Stool microscopy: acid-fast staining oocysts or immunofluorescent assay
  • Intestinal biopsy: organisms on mucosal brush border

Treatment

  • Immunocompetent: supportive care only
  • Immunocompromised*: nitazoxanide

*Patients with HIV should be started on antiretroviral therapy first & treated with antimicrobial therapy only if symptoms persist.

Infectious diarrhea is common in patients with HIV; disease course and microbiology usually reflect the degree of immune dysfunction.  Patients with low CD4 counts, especially <200/mm3, can develop severe prolonged diarrhea from pathogens including Cryptosporidium, Cyclospora, Mycobacterium avium complex, and cytomegalovirus (CMV).  Patients with HIV with normal CD4 counts (eg, >500/mm3), as in this case, can still be affected by these pathogens, but their disease course is typically milder and similar to that of immunocompetent patients.

Of the choices provided, the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is Cryptosporidium parvum, a protozoan that can infect both immunocompetent and immunocompromised patients but typically causes only self-limited (10-14 days) symptoms in patients with normal CD4 counts.  Malaise, nausea, bloating, and abdominal cramping are also typical, and weight loss can occur due to profuse volume loss from the secretory diarrhea.  Ingestion of contaminated water is the most common method of spread, but transmission can occur by accidentally ingesting oocysts from an infected farm animal, which likely occurred in this case.

Diagnosis can be confirmed via stool PCR testing or stool microscopy with modified acid-fast stain revealing oocytes; fecal leukocyte and blood testing is typically negative because Cryptosporidium causes noninflammatory diarrhea.  Treatment is generally supportive for immunocompetent patients.  Initiation of antiretroviral therapy in patients with HIV with low CD4 counts alone may resolve symptoms due to immune reconstitution; those with persistent symptoms can be treated with nitazoxanide.

(Choice B)  CMV enterocolitis usually occurs in patients with HIV who are not on antiretroviral therapy and who have CD4 counts <50/mm3, not seen here.  In addition, CMV causes an inflammatory diarrhea that often presents with hematochezia; stool testing for leukocytes and occult blood is usually positive.

(Choice C)  Mycobacterium avium complex infection occurs almost exclusively in patients with severely suppressed CD4 counts (<50/mm3).  Moreover, infection is typically disseminated and associated with high-grade fever (>39 C [102 F]), which is not seen in this patient.

(Choice D)  Nontyphoidal Salmonella (eg, S Enteritidis) causes acute (<1 week) inflammatory diarrhea.  This patient's prolonged symptoms and noninflammatory diarrhea make this diagnosis less likely.

(Choice E)  Strongyloides stercoralis can cause diarrhea, but cutaneous and pulmonary symptoms would also be expected.

Educational objective:
Cryptosporidium causes self-limited, watery (noninflammatory) diarrhea in immunocompetent hosts, including patients with HIV who have normal CD4 counts.  Immunocompromised patients (eg, AIDS) can develop prolonged, severe diarrhea.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Chronic diarrhea

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Cryptosporidium infection: epidemiology, pathogenesis, and differential diagnosis.

questionList.questionText:
A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to 5 days of intermittent high fever, chills, and drenching sweats.  He also has malaise, fatigue, and dark urine.  The patient has no medical history other than a splenectomy after a motor vehicle collision 10 years ago.  He drinks alcohol on social occasions and does not use tobacco or recreational drugs.  The patient is in a monogamous relationship with his wife.  He lives on Long Island, New York, and works in Manhattan as a software programmer.  The patient has not traveled outside the country but recently went camping in New England and found 2 ticks on his legs when he returned home.  Temperature is 39.5 C (103.1 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 116/min.  Mild scleral icterus is present.  There are no enlarged lymph nodes or rashes.  A mildly tender liver edge is palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
Hemoglobin9.4 g/dL
Reticulocytes10%
Platelets110,000/mm3
Leukocytes12,000/mm3
Liver function studies
Total bilirubin4.3 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase92 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT)62 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT)74 U/L
Serum lactate dehydrogenase300 U/L

Which of the following is most likely to help confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Babesiosis

Epidemiology

  • Babesia microti
  • Ixodes scapularis tick bite (Lyme disease & HGA)
  • Northeastern United States

Clinical
manifestations

  • Fever, fatigue, myalgia, headache (flu-like symptoms)
  • If severe: ARDS, CHF, DIC, splenic rupture
  • Anemia, thrombocytopenia, increased bilirubin/LDH/LFTs

Diagnosis

  • Thin blood smear: intraerythrocytic rings ("Maltese cross")

Treatment

  • Atovaquone + azithromycin
  • Quinine + clindamycin (if severe)

ARDS = acute respiratory distress syndrome; CHF = congestive heart failure; DIC = disseminated intravascular coagulation; HGA = human granulocytic anaplasmosis; LDH = lactate dehydrogenase; LFTs = liver function tests.

Babesiosis is a tick-borne protozoal illness endemic to the northeastern United States.  It is transmitted by the Ixodes scapularis tick approximately 48-72 hours after attachment.  Because I scapularis also transmits Borrelia burgdorferi (Lyme disease) and Anaplasma phagocytophilum (human granulocytic anaplasmosis), coinfection is fairly common.  Peak prevalence is in July and August, when tick populations are at their highest.

Infection is often asymptomatic or mild, but patients with immunocompromise, age >50, or asplenia are at higher risk for severe illness.  Symptoms typically include the gradual onset of fatigue, malaise, weakness, chills, and fever.  The organism multiplies in red blood cells, so patients may develop anemia with signs of intravascular hemolysis (eg, jaundice, dark urine, indirect hyperbilirubinemia, reticulocytosis, elevations of aminotransferases and lactate dehydrogenase).  Thrombocytopenia is common, and mild hepatosplenomegaly may occur.  The diagnosis is made by identifying organisms on peripheral blood smear ("Maltese cross").  Treatment includes 7-10 days of atovaquone plus azithromycin or quinine plus clindamycin (for severe illness).  Symptoms may take up to 3 months to fully resolve.

(Choice A)  Rocky Mountain spotted fever is also transmitted by a tick bite.  Symptoms often include fever, headache, myalgia, and a prominent rash (macular/petechial) that spreads centripetally (from the periphery toward the center) and includes the palms and soles.  Hemolytic anemia is uncommon.

(Choice C)  Lyme disease is also transmitted by I scapularis.  Early disease is usually characterized by erythema migrans (a punched-out, spreading rash), fever, myalgia, headache, and/or lymphadenopathy.  Anemia with intravascular hemolysis is not a feature of this illness.

(Choice D)  Ehrlichiosis is a tick-borne (Amblyomma americanum) illness that causes nonspecific symptoms (eg, fever, myalgia, headache) and leukopenia/thrombocytopenia.  It primarily occurs in the southeastern, south-central, and mid-Atlantic United States, rather than the northeastern United States (due to the geographic distribution of the transmitting tick).  This patient with leukocytosis and signs of intravascular hemolysis is more likely to have babesiosis.

(Choice E)  The diagnosis of dengue fever can be aided by using the tourniquet test, which involves inflating a blood pressure cuff on the arm to a point halfway between diastolic and systolic pressures and examining for petechiae 5 minutes later.  Dengue fever is often asymptomatic, but some patients develop fever and severe myalgia/headache (breakbone fever).  Leukopenia (not leukocytosis) and thrombocytopenia are common.  Intravascular hemolysis would be atypical.

(Choice F)  Acute viral hepatitis is usually characterized by fever, vomiting, jaundice, abdominal pain, and dramatic elevations in aminotransferases (>1,000 U/L).

Educational objective:
Babesiosis is a tick-borne protozoal illness found primarily in the northeastern United States.  Transmission occurs via the Ixodes scapularis tick, and coinfection with other microbes (eg, Borrelia burgdorferi, Anaplasma phagocytophilum) can occur.  Symptoms are often flu-like (eg, fever, chills, malaise), and laboratory studies usually show anemia with signs of intravascular hemolysis and thrombocytopenia.  The diagnosis is made primarily by identifying organisms on peripheral blood smear ("Maltese cross").
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Babesiosis

questionList.questionText:
A 34-year-old man comes to the office during summer due to intensely pruritic lesions on his right foot.  The patient has no chronic medical conditions and has never had similar symptoms before.  He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and drinks alcohol on social occasions.  The patient works as a landscaper and recently went to a company barbeque lunch.  His vital signs are normal.  Physical examination findings are shown below.

Which of the following most likely occurred before the patient developed these symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
Cutaneous larva migrans

Epidemiology

  • Hookworm larvae
    • Dog (Ancylostoma caninum) or cat (A braziliense)
  • Humans are incidental hosts
  • Barefoot contact with contaminated sand or soil

Clinical

  • Primarily lower extremity
  • Cutaneous (deeper infection rare)
  • Erythematous, pruritic papule at site of entry
  • Intensely pruritic, migrating, serpiginous, reddish-brown tracks

Diagnosis

  • History & clinical findings
  • Eosinophils usually normal

Treatment

  • Antihelmintic (eg, ivermectin)

Cutaneous larva migrans (CLM) is a creeping cutaneous eruption caused by dog (Ancylostoma caninum) or cat (A braziliense) hookworm larvae.  Most infections are acquired from walking barefoot on contaminated sand (beaches) or soil.  Humans are incidental hosts, and larvae are typically unable to penetrate the dermal basement membrane.  As a result, cutaneous infection without deeper penetration is the norm.

Most infections occur in the lower extremities (~70%), and symptoms usually start with a pruritic, erythematous papule at the site of larvae penetration (which may go unnoticed).  Within a few days, patients develop symptoms related to larvae migration: intensely pruritic, serpiginous, reddish-brown cutaneous tracks.  Although most cases resolve spontaneously after a few weeks, antihelmintics (eg, ivermectin) are usually given to aid clearance.

(Choice A)  Brown recluse spider bites occur most commonly on the upper arm, thorax, or inner thighs.  Bites are characterized by a red plaque or papule with central clearing; some patients develop a necrotic eschar.  This patient with a lower extremity, pruritic, serpiginous lesion is more likely to have CLM.

(Choice B)  Consumption of undercooked, contaminated pork can lead to gastrointestinal infection with the tapeworm Taenia solium.  Most patients are asymptomatic, but some develop nausea, anorexia, or abdominal pain.  Cutaneous manifestations are atypical.  T solium eggs may pass via the fecal-oral route, causing cysticercosis.

(Choice C)  Urushiol is the irritant component of poison ivy, poison oak, and poison sumac.  Patients often develop intensely pruritic, linear, vesicular (or plaque or bullous) lesions.  Although there is a small bullous area on this patient's lesion, the presence of a serpiginous (not linear) rash makes urushiol irritation much less likely than CLM.

(Choice D)  Sporotrichosis is a fungal infection that can arise after exposure to decaying vegetation when gardening or landscaping.  Symptoms include a nodule that usually ulcerates and drains an odorless, nonpurulent fluid.  Additional nodular lesions may arise proximally along the lymphatic chain.  Pruritus is usually absent or mild.

Educational objective:
Cutaneous larva migrans is a creeping cutaneous eruption due to dog (Ancylostoma caninum) or cat (A braziliense) hookworm larvae.  Most infections arise from walking barefoot on contaminated sand or soil.  Symptoms include a pruritic, papular lesion at the portal of entry and intensely pruritic, migrating, serpiginous reddish-brown tracks.  Ivermectin is typically given to speed resolution and clearance.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Hookworm

answerChoiceList.choice: Bite from a brown recluse spider
Contact with plant sap containing urushiol
Walking barefoot on a sandy beach

questionList.questionText: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the office for evaluation of "itchy private parts" for the past week.  Her mother has noticed the scratching at bedtime but not during the day.  Due to the itching, the patient has difficulty falling asleep.  Her mother has been applying a topical emollient with only minimal symptom relief.  The patient has no urinary symptoms and has soft bowel movements once every other day.  She attends daycare during the week and lives with her mother, stepfather, and 13-year-old stepbrother, none of whom have similar symptoms.  Physical examination shows an erythematous vulva and no vaginal discharge.  The perianal area is excoriated and diffusely erythematous.  No other lesions are noted.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm)

Pathogenesis

  • Transmission via ingestion of eggs
  • Larvae develop into adult worms in the intestines
  • Female worms migrate to the perianal region at night & deposit eggs

Findings

  • Nocturnal perianal pruritus → perianal erythema/excoriations*

Diagnosis

  • Mobile worms visualized near anal verge
  • Tape test: eggs visualized under microscopic examination

Treatment**

  • Albendazole, mebendazole, or pyrantel pamoate
  • Administered to patient & household contacts, then repeated in 2 weeks

*Worm migration to vulvar region may also cause symptoms of vulvovaginitis (eg, vulvar itching & erythema).

**Empiric treatment (ie, without visualization of eggs/worms) can be performed for those with classic findings.

Pinworm (Enterobius vermicularis) is a common helminth infection in school-age children and typically presents with nocturnal perianal pruritus (pruritus ani).  Transmission occurs via contact with contaminated objects (eg, bedding, clothing) or unwashed hands after scratching the perianal area.  Although adult worms live in the intestines, females migrate distally to deposit eggs onto the perianal skin, primarily at night, causing symptoms.  Mature pinworms can also spread to the vagina and cause vulvovaginitis, as seen in this child.

Diagnosis is made via the "tape test," in which an adhesive is pressed on the perianal area (ideally in the morning or at night) and eggs and/or pinworms are visualized on the adherent material under microscopy.  Treatment with albendazole or pyrantel pamoate is recommended for the patient and other individuals in the household to avoid reinfection.

(Choice A)  Candida vulvovaginitis presents with vaginal pruritus, erythema, and discharge, usually in the setting of recent antibiotic use.  Vaginal candidiasis does not cause perianal abnormalities.

(Choice B)  Contact dermatitis can manifest as nonspecific vulvovaginitis due to a topical irritant (eg, bubble bath, restrictive clothing).  However, symptoms typically are present throughout the day, and perianal itching is not expected.

(Choice D)  Lichen sclerosus can cause perianal and vulvar pruritus as well as vaginal discharge or bleeding.  Findings include hypopigmentation and ecchymoses of the affected area, not seen on this patient's examination.

(Choice E)  Neisseria gonorrhoeae cervicitis is a sexually transmitted infection that typically presents with vaginal discharge, not seen in this patient.

(Choice F)  Scabies is a mite infection that presents with intensely pruritic papules usually involving the interdigital web spaces, axillae, wrists, and genitalia.  This patient's localized perianal and vulvar erythema is more consistent with a pinworm infection.

Educational objective:
Pinworm infection typically presents with nocturnal perianal pruritus and can cause vulvar and perianal erythema.  Diagnosis is confirmed by visualization of eggs and/or pinworms on the "tape test."  Treatment is with albendazole or pyrantel pamoate.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Intestinal helminth parasites

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Vulvovaginitis in childhood.
Pruritis ani:  diagnosis and treatment.

questionList.questionText: A 42-year-old man comes to the office due to progressive upper abdominal discomfort and nausea over several weeks.  He was a farmer in rural Guatemala before immigrating to the United States 5 years ago.  Temperature is 36.9 C (98.4 F), blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg, and pulse is 68/min.  Cardiopulmonary examination is normal.  Hepatomegaly is present.  There is no lower extremity edema.  Liver ultrasonography shows a 10-cm, smooth, round cyst with daughter cysts inside.  Which of the following is most likely to be associated with this patient's current condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Echinococcus granulosus

Epidemiology

  • Dog tapeworm (sheep intermediate host)
  • Rural, developing countries (eg, South America, Middle East)
  • Humans are incidental hosts (egg ingestion)

Manifestations

  • Initially asymptomatic (often for years)
  • Liver cyst (most common)
    • Mass effect: RUQ pain, nausea, vomiting, hepatomegaly
    • Rupture: fever, eosinophilia
  • Lung cyst: cough, chest pain, hemoptysis

Diagnosis

  • Large, smooth hydatid cyst often with internal septations on imaging
  • IgG E granulosus serology

Treatment

  • Albendazole
  • Percutaneous therapy (>5 cm or septations)
  • Surgery (if rupture)

RUQ = right upper quadrant.

Echinococcus granulosus is a dog tapeworm endemic to rural, developing countries.  Prevalence is particularly high in areas of sheep farming (sheep are intermediate hosts), as dogs are often fed sheep viscera.  Humans acquire the infection incidentally after ingesting food or water contaminated by dog feces.  Eggs hatch in the small intestine, penetrate the intestinal wall, and travel to the liver (or, less commonly, lung) where hydatid cysts form.  Many patients remain asymptomatic for years and develop clinical illness only due to large cyst size (>10 cm) or rupture.

Manifestations include right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and hepatomegaly.  Rupture may result in fever.  Ultrasound has excellent sensitivity (~95%) and typically shows a large, smooth hepatic cyst often with daughter cysts (internal septations).  Positive serology for E granulosus IgG corroborates the diagnosis (sensitivity ~95%) and usually obviates the need for percutaneous biopsy.  "Eggshell" calcification of a hepatic cyst on CT scan is highly suggestive of a hydatid cyst.

Small cysts (<5 cm) are typically treated with albendazole; larger or complex cysts usually also require percutaneous therapy or surgery.

(Choice B)  Eating contaminated pork may result in a Taenia solium gastrointestinal tapeworm infection.  Humans can transmit tapeworm eggs to others, causing cysticercosis.  Cysticercosis usually affects the brain (seizures) or cerebral ventricular system (intracranial hypertension); liver cysts are uncommon.

(Choice C)  Entamoeba histolytica is often asymptomatic but may cause dysentery/colitis and liver abscess.  Amebic abscess usually manifests with fever, right upper quadrant pain, and a smooth, cystic, subcapsular mass.  This patient is afebrile and has a cystic lesion with daughter cysts, making E granulosus more likely.

(Choice D)  Undercooked fish may transmit liver flukes (eg, Clonorchis sinensis) or fish tapeworm (eg, Diphyllobothrium latum).  Liver flukes typically cause biliary disease (not hepatic cysts).  Fish tapeworm rarely causes symptoms but may cause megaloblastic anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency.

(Choice E)  Prolonged and excessive alcohol intake increases the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma, which may cause weight loss, abdominal pain, and complications related to rupture or tissue compression.  Imaging typically reveals a dense, irregular mass (not a cystic, smooth mass).

Educational objective:
Echinococcus granulosus is a dog tapeworm endemic to rural, developing countries.  Humans are incidental hosts and usually acquire the infection through the consumption of food or water contaminated with dog feces.  Tapeworm eggs hatch in the small intestine and spread to the viscera (eg, liver, lung), causing hydatid cysts.  Symptoms are initially rare, but hepatic cysts may grow over time, resulting in right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and hepatomegaly.  Imaging typically reveals a large, smooth cyst, often with internal septations.
questionList.subject: Surgery
questionList.title: Echinococcosis

answerChoiceList.choice: Dysentery within the previous few months
